titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0050, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Epistles Lectionary leaves in Greek. Contains 33 lections for Lent, Holy Week, and various feasts. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 3.
The manuscript is commonly known as the Haskell Lectionary because it was initially housed in the Haskell Oriental Museum of the University of Chicago.

initials.p: Major initials (20-40 mm) set off from the text in red (faded).

physDesc.extent: 8 leaves, of which 2 are flyleaves of parchment contemporary with the manuscript's rebinding of 1897.

foliation.p: 1 (unfoliated parchment flyleaf) + 6 + 1 (unfoliated paper flyleaf). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 268-273. The leaves were bound at the end of Ms. 46, and the foliation completed before the gospel manuscript and lectionary leaves were separated.

layout.p: 1 column, 39-43 lines. Frame ruling with hard point.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in dark brown ink (some flaking).
Punctuation includes high point, comma, marks of elision and interrogation.

textDivisions.p: Titles in red (faded). Contains date, or holy day, and epistle source.

condition.p: Torn leaf (fol. 268). Moderately cockled. Water and dirt stains. Insect damage.

binding.p: Bound in brown morocco by Stikeman & Company. Shelf number in gold on front cover.

origin.p: The manuscript to which the present leaves belonged is judged to have been written in the 13th century in Greece.

provenance.p: Medieval to late 19th century provenance unknown. Belonged to Pericles Morades, who is said to have brought the lectionary leaves (bound with Ms. 46) to the United States from the Greek island of Thera.
Marginal notes in Syriac in pencil. University of Chicago Libraries bookplate (front pastedown). Notation (fols. 269v, 273v).

acquisition.p: Acquired by Caspar René Gregory and Ernest DeWitt Burton for the University of Chicago from Constantine Mitchell, executor of the Pericles Morades estate, September 12, 1895.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Epistles Lectionary leaves in Greek. Contains 33 lections for Lent, Holy Week, and various feasts. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 3.
The manuscript is commonly known as the Haskell Lectionary because it was initially housed in the Haskell Oriental Museum of the University of Chicago.

msItem.summary: Sunday, Week 1 of Lent, Hebrews 11:31 (lacking, begins with [πι]στει).
Presentation of Jesus in the temple, Hebrews 7:7-17.
